An absolute pleasure to play through. Ricochet goes where no other Valve game has ever been before - You take control of Pert Kravelski, another overlooked escapee of the Black Mesa Research Facility introduced in Valve's hit title 'Half-Life' whose goal throughout the entire game is to discover the Saisei code (which I won't spoil for you who don't know what that is).  Since Pert's family was kidnapped by the Task Force which invaded the Black Mesa Research Facility in Half-Life, his goal is to break into the barracks of the Task Force and retreive his family, after wasting each and every soldier in the facility, but there is an extremely poetic, creative and unexpected plot-twist which prevents you from doing so (this is the meat of the story)  The game runs unbelievably smooth for the time it was made, and the graphics are just stunning. I can't fathom why the Valve fanbase completely dismissed this game, as its feature-set, physics, *and* graphics rival that of Half-Life 2.   Buy. This. Game.

Ricochet is a multiplayer deathmatch game, which attempts to be original and has virtual/arcade feel to it. It was a free modification for Half-Life, coming along with one of the patches to the game, and from what I know, it was supposed to show new additions to the engine, as well as just being a bonus. Yet now it's being sold on Steam serapately. And in this case, it wasn't a good move.  And well... Player base of this multiplayer game is dead. Completely. And is the main reason not to recommend this for purchase.  Otherwise, the game is not horrible. It was good for what it was supposed to be - bonus mod. You jump between platforms using boosters and throw discs at opponents, either to push them off into void or to kill them. You regenerate discs ammo all time up to 3 of them. Pushing requires 1 discs, thus can be spammed. Decapating disc wastes all 3 'ammo'. There is regular respawning power-up. And with usage of HL Engine advanced maneuvering (air strafing) you can try to outsmart enemies by landing on different platform than what is expected. And most often, you will fall into void due to your own clunkyness. Or bump into another player and fall down together. It's just that it tried to push on art direction of 'arcade/virtual' style too much, thus it lacks any casual fun of 'shoot them the terrorists from awesome guns', nor does it has any pleasent art in levels themselves. Otherwise, nice bonus mod, for 2-4 players DMing.

There are two game modes (as far as I know): arena (one-on-one matches) and deathmatch. This game was an idea in which one could make a popular game with a short budget and a simple set of rules. It did successfully but with short lived fame. It's fun to play with friends but keep in mind that friends is all you've got because the community is pretty lifeless with some bots. If you want to play the game, be sure that you have friends who are willing to buy as well. To this day I got a very vague understanding of what this game is, what is happening on its (very few) confusing maps and what are you supposed to do in order to progress.  From what I was able to comprehend the challenge consists of  trying to figure out what is going on , aiming your attacks at your fellow players who are constantly on the move and jump around platforms very fast, remembering the map layout so that you can better adjust your movement, and trying not to accidentally fall off into pitch-black nowhere while moving yourself and dodging your opponent attacks.  The attacks themselves are performed by launching some sort of futuristic bola (disc-shaped thingy) at other players with intent to throw them off of their platforms and make you score. Although it doesn’t seem to work all the time (?), or the hit detection is not very good/reliable.  The point is that most of the time you need to “predict” your opponent’s future location and aim your disc accordingly as aiming at players directly would almost never work since the movement speed is just so fast and everything is so chaotic. That’s again why good knowldge of the map is a key since knowing where your opponent would most likely go increases your chances at hitting them with your disc significantly.  But I’m sure there’s more to it as map design is pretty awkward and complicated. The above described process is pretty much all that happens each round of the game.   Anyway , the game design is very convoluted and if I were to describe Ricochet with just one phrase, I’d say it’s an ill-conceived fusion of Tron, unfinished Half-Life Xen levels and Quake deathmatch happening inside some Black Mesa scientist’s drug-induced hallucination.  There are simply much better puzzle games out there ( Portal  being a most obvious alternative) which have better environments, better (sane) game design and better gameplay.  Actually, I’m not even sure how this got officially released. It appears that at some point Valve thought that they actually are making some good game rather than hacking together some perverted deathmatch mode for Half-Life. It should have been released as a free mod at most, serving as an example, – but even then it would still seem weird.  It’s OK if you got it with your Valve pack purchase, but if you are bying it alone you are probably crazy or just very curious.
